PDA = (K, Σ, Γ, δ, q0, Z, F)
LBA = (K, Σ, Γ, δ, q0, F)
TM = (K, Σ, Γ, δ, q0, F)
supervised by doc. Mgr. Daniela Chudá, PhD.

CMSimulator app helps you better understand four of the most well-known abstract machines - finite state automaton, push-down automaton, linear-bounded automaton and Turing machine. You can create new or load existing solutions from files. The application also contains eight examples (one deterministic and one nondeterministic for each type of the machine).

You can create a list of symbols, states, transition rules and also choose the initial and final states. Then you can fill the tape and simulate the solution step by step, or go directly to the end of simulation. You can also mark any tape element as breakpoint to pause the simulation when the machine reaches this breakpoint.
Nondeterministic machines and solutions are also supported.
Since version 3, the application also allows the creation and solving of interactive assignments over the local area network.
The application was developed as part of several bachelor\'s projects by students of the Faculty of Informatics and Information Technologies of the Slovak University of Technology in Bratislava.

Since version 4, the application has been extended by simulation and visualization of formal grammars from the Chomsky hierarchy. In CMSimulator you can create, analyze and test Regular, Context-free, Context-sensitive and Unrestricted grammars. The application support saving and loading existing grammars, as well as 4 different kinds of visualizations - Derivation Table, Derivation Tree, Linear derivation and Fixed derivation.

To create a new machine, tap the New Machine button in the main menu, then select what type of machine you would like to create. You will be taken to the Configuration Activity, where you can edit and save your new machine.

If you would like to view an example machine created in CMSimulator, tap the Example Machines button in the main menu and select which machine you would like to open. You will be taken to the Simulation Activity where you can try the machine out.

If you would like to view an example grammar created in CMSimulator, tap the Example Grammars button in the main menu and select which grammar you would like to open. You will be taken to the Grammar Activity where you can try the grammar out.

The available example machines are:\n \t \u2022 A deterministic finite automaton accepting words with 3k+1 characters\n \t \u2022 A deterministic finite automaton accepting words in the form of a

The available example grammars are:\n \t \u2022 A regular grammar accepting words in the form of a

To load a previously-saved machine, tap the Load Machine button in the main menu, then select the file you would like to open.

To enter the Tasks menu, tap the Tasks button in the main menu. Then, to solve tasks currently assigned by people in your vicinity, tap the Find Tasks button. To create a new task for others to solve, tap the New Task button. To load a task you have previously prepared, tap the Load Task button.
To enter the Grammar menu, tap the Grammar button in the main menu. You will be taken to the grammar definition screen, where you can define or load the grammar you would like to work with.
To view or change the application\'s settings, tap the Settings button in the main menu.

The Configuration Activity is where you can create and edit your machines. You can define the machine\'s alphabet, add or remove states and declare transitions. The activity is divided into a number of tabs, each dedicated to a different action.
The menu in this activity allows you to save the machine, view the formal specification, or move to the Simulation Activity, Bulk Testing Activity, or Settings.

In the Diagram tab you can view and edit the state diagram of the machine. You can select a tool from the bottom panel to edit the diagram.\n\ You can zoom the diagram in and out by pinching the screen in the diagram area.
Move - while this tool is selected, you can drag the states around. Drag the empty space around states to pan the entire diagram.
New State - tap anywhere in the diagram to place a new state there.

New Transition - touch the initial state of the transition and drag to the final state of the transition. A popup window will appear where you can specify other properties of the transition, such as the read symbol.
Edit - tap a state or transition to edit it.
Remove - tap a state or transition to remove it.

The other tabs let you define different properties of the machine individually. All machines have a tab for input alphabet, states and transitions. Push-down automata also have a tab for the stack alphabet. You can add new elements by tapping the button at the bottom of the activity.

Some symbols in the input alphabet and the stack alphabet have a special significance. Special symbols are automatically inserted into the alphabet when the machine is created and cannot be removed. However, you can customize some of them.

ε (epsilon) - the empty symbol for finite automata and push-down automata. Creating a transition with epsilon as the read symbol signifies that the transition may be performed without reading any symbol. Epsilon transitions are inherently nondeterministic - the machine may or may not choose to perform them at all (though a push-down automaton may be forced to if it is the only viable transition for the current state of the stack). Epsilon cannot be part of the input word.\n Epsilon is also used as a stack symbol with similar semantics - placing epsilon on the stack means nothing will be placed, and popping epsilon off the stack means nothing gets popped.
# (blank symbol) - the default tape symbol for linear-bounded automata and Turing machines. This symbol can be customized.
Z (stack start symbol) - the symbol that is automatically placed at the bottom of the stack before the simulation starts. This symbol can be customized.

|< (left end) - marks the left end of the linear-bounded automaton\'s tape. It is inserted just before the simulation starts, and is ignored for the purposes of "expected output" in the Bulk Test Activity. It can be used as an input symbol in transitions, but it cannot be overwritten and the machine\'s head cannot move left of it. This symbol can be customized.

>| (right end) - marks the right end of the linear-bounded automaton\'s tape. It is inserted just before the simulation starts, and is ignored for the purposes of "expected output" in the Bulk Test Activity. It can be used as an input symbol in transitions, but it cannot be overwritten and the machine\'s head cannot move right of it.

In the Simulation Activity, you can set the content of the machine's tape and simulate it fully to see whether or not the input gets accepted, or sep-by-step and watch how the machine is working. The activity provides you with an overview about the machine's current state, current state of the tape (and, for push-down automata, stack), and history of transitions.
For nondeterministic machines, the state and tape of every branch of the computation is shown, labelled with different color.
You can use the slider on the right edge of the screen to change the ratio between the display areas of the state diagram and the transition history diagram.
The state diagram and the transition history diagram can be zoomed in and out by pinching the screen in their respective areas.
The menu in this activity allows you to save the machine, view the formal specification, clear the tape, or move to the Configuration Activity, Bulk Testing Activity, or Settings.
The tape is shown at the top of the screen. It can only be manipulated while a simulation is not in progress.
Add tape element - tap to add a new element at the respective end of the tape.
Tape element - tap to set the symbol on the tape element. Tap and hold to open a context menu.

The tape element context menu offers you the following options:
\ 	 • Set as Initial Tape Element - the machine's head will be set to this element at the start of the simulation.
\ 	 • Place/Remove Breakpoint - mark the tape element as breakpoint, or clears away the breakpoint. See the "Breakpoints" section for more information.
\ 	 • Remove - remove the tape element.
Step back - undo the last step of the simulation.
Step forward - simulate one step of the machine.
Simulate fully - simulate the machine until it stops, or until it performs the maximum number of steps (100 by default, can be changed in Settings).
Stop - stop the simulation, allowing you to edit the tape.
Remove breakpoints -Removes all breakpoints. See the "Breakpoints" section for more information.

Breakpoints help you to analyze the machine\'s behaviour at a specific point without having to run the entire simulation step-by-step. When "simulating fully", the machine will pause just before reading a symbol marked with breakpoint. A nondeterministic machine will pause if any branch of executions reaches a breakpoint. You can resume the simulation by tapping the Simulate fully button again (the machine will pause again after reaching the next breakpoint), or you can proceed step-by-step from that point.\nBreakpoints are marked on the tape in red color.

This activity allows you to define several input words and quickly run them all on your machine, informing you which ones were accepted. This lets you easily verify the correctness of your solutions. For linear-bounded automate and Turing machines, you can also check whether the machine produces a particular output. For nondeterministic machines, the output is considered valid if it matches the output of any possible path.
The menu in this activity allows you to save the machine, view the formal specification, or move to the Configuration Activity, Simulation Activity, or Settings.

Running an input may end in one of the following results:
 Accepted - the input was accepted and if you set and expected output, the output was also correct.
 Took too long - the machine was stopped after executing the maximum number of steps (100 by default, can be changed in the Settings).
 Correct output, rejected - the input was rejected, but the output word matches the expected one. This result only appears if you have set the expected output word.
 Rejected - the input was rejected. If the output word is set, the output is also incorrect.
 Incorrect output - the input was accepted, but the output word does not match the expected one. This result only appears if you have set the expected output word.
If you would like to more closely observe the machine\'s behaviour for a specific input, tap and hold the input in the list and you will be offered an option to test it in the Simulation Activity.
To create a new testing input, tap the Add New Test button. To run the tests, tap the Run Tests button.
Saving and Loading Machines and Tasks

You can save the machine you are working with via the menu button in most activities. The machines are saved into the CMSolutions folder on your device. Saved machines can be subsequently loaded via the Load Machine button in the main menu.\nTasks can be saved via the menu button in the Task Editing Activity and loaded via the Load Task button in the Tasks Menu.

When saving a machine, you are offered to choose the file format. The CMS format is CMSimulator\'s native and preferred format. JFF is a file format used by the JFLAP formal machine simulator for desktop devices. It is strongly recommended to use the CMS format unless you want to later work with the machine using JFLAP, because the CMS format is specifically tailored for the CMSimulation application and supports features not supported by JFLAP, such as storing the machine tape.\nSaving a task generates a file with the .cmst extension. This extension indicates the file contains a task, but internally they use the same format as plain CMS files and can be used interchangeably with them.

In addition to allowing you to create and simulate abstract machines, CMSimulator also provides a platform for solving interactive tasks. Using the Tasks Menu, you can either create tasks for others to solve, or find tasks assigned to you by other users in the local network.

The goal of a task is to create a machine that matches given criteria. The machine can be evaluated based on whether or not it accepts the inputs it is supposed to accept, rejects the inputs it is supposed to reject, and generates the outputs it is supposed to generate. The machine is simulated for up to the maximum number of steps set by the assigner in their Settings, and inputs for which the machine runs too long are considered to be rejected. The task is typically described verbally, and the actual tests that are run may or may not be shown to the solvers, based on how the assigner decides.

To find tasks currently being assigned by people in your local network, tap the Find Tasks button in the Tasks Menu. The application will automatically connect to nearby devices and show the list of available tasks. If you are not seeing a task that should be available, you can try reloading them using the Refresh button.
Detail - show details about the task and offer option to solve it.

If you are allowed to view the evaluation inputs, the Bulk Testing option in menus will be replaced by two separate options - Correct Inputs and Incorrect Inputs. You can view and launch these tests, but you cannot remove or edit them.
Task info - tap this button to show the task popup, allowing you to read the assignment again, see how much time you have left, and turn in the task.

To create a new task, tap the New Task button in the Tasks Menu. To load a previously saved task, tap the Load Task button. You will be taken to the Task Editing Activity, where you can set the task\'s properties and edit the associated machine.

In the Task Editing Activity, you can set the task\'s title, verbal assignment, time limit, and whether or not you wish to share the test inputs with the solvers. Tap the Set Test Inputs and Machine button to set the test inputs and edit the associated machine.
The menu in this activity allows you to save the task, view Help or go to Settings.

Tap the Launch Task button to launch the task, allowing users in the local network to find it and start solving it. You will see the names of the solvers who turn the task in, along with the number of positive and negative tests their machine passed. Tap the Stop Task button to prevent any more people from finding the task or turning it in. The displayed timer is purely informative - the time limit is enforced by the application on solver\'s side.\nYou can save the displayed results as a text file via the menu.

While editing the machine associated with the task, the Bulk Testing option in menus will be replaced by two separate options - Correct Inputs and Incorrect Inputs, where you can set the testing inputs that will be used to evaluate the solutions.
Task info - tap this button to show the task popup, allowing you to check the assignment and return to the Task Edit Activity.

Maximum number of automatically simulated steps - the maximum number of steps that will be executed after pressing the simulate fully button in the Simulation activity, as well as the maximum number of steps for which each input in the Bulk Testing Activity is simulated.
Mark nondeterministic transitions - all nondeterministic transitions in the transition diagrams in the Configuration and Simulation activities will be shown in red.
Machine colors - edit the colors that will be assigned to the machines during simulation.

In the grammar definition activity you can define the rules of your own grammar or alternatively load them from external .CMSG or .JFF files. After te grammar is defined you can check various information about it and proceed to testing.
The menu in this activity allows you to create a new grammar, load or save existing ones and access the help page.

You can define the rules of your grammar in this table by entering the rules to the left columns and derivations to the right column. If there are several derivations from the same rule, you can divide them by
pipe
(See Grammar special symbols). If you wish to enter an empty word, please use epsilon (See Grammar special symbols). Since these characters are uncommon on Android keyboards you can enter them by pressing the shortcut buttons. If you run out of rows in the table, you can add more by pressing the Add row button.

In the grammar definition table you can see various information about the entered grammar including the type of the grammar in the Chomsky hierarchy, its formal definition, the used terminals and non-terminals.

In the grammar simulation activity you can test, simulate and visualize the derivation of words from the grammar rules. You can test words if they belong to the defined language and visualize them using either a derivation table, derivation tree, linear derivation or fixed derivation. Furthermore you can analyze the whole derivation sequence by stepping forward and backwards.
The menu in this activity allows you to switch back and forth between the 4 available kinds of visualizations and access the help page.

The input testing allows you to enter words to the text field and check if the input word belongs to the defined language by pressing the Test input button. You can use the Clear button the clear the content of the input field. If you wish to test the empty word, please leave the input field clear.

During the simulation process, you can step forward and backwards by selecting the appropriate buttons on the bottom of the screen. Each time a button is selected a different step of the simulation is shown on the screen.

The derivation tree visualizes the derivation sequence by drawing nodes for each symbol of each derivation and connecting them with lines. Each step of the simulation is represented by a new depth of the tree. The non-terminal symbols are colored yellow while the terminal symbols are colored green. At the end of the simulation the green nodes show the result.
The derivation table visualizes the derivation sequence by showing the used rule and the output word next to each other in each step of the simulation.

The linear derivation visualizes the derivation sequence by writing the generated words in each step of the simulation in one line. The replaced part of the word is coloured yellow, while the new part of the word is coloured green. At the end of the simulation the result is shown underlined and bold.

The fixed derivation visualizes the derivation sequence by showing the current word in one place in each step of the simulation. Apart from that a list of all the used rules are shown under the current word. In each step of the simulation the new parts of the word is coloured green and at the end of the simulation the result is shown underlined and bold.

In this activity you can test multiple words simultaneously if the belong to the defined language. Furthermore you can also express your opinion by selecting which words do you think belong to the language and which do not.
The menu in this activity allows you to access the help page.

The multiple tests table is divided into two parts. In the left column you can enter the words you wish to be tested. In the right column you can you can enter your guess for each word. By default the check box is set to empty, if you tap once, a tick appears which means that the word should belong to the language. By tapping twice you select the option that you do not think, that the word is accepted byt the language. If you tap once more, the check box resets to the default state, where nothing is selected. By selecting the Clear button you clear the contents of the whole table.

By pressing the Test all button, the entered words and guesses are evaluated and the result is shown on the screen. In the left column of the table, each row is coloured accordingly, if the entered word belongs to the language, the background appears in green colour, if it does not belong, the colouring will be red. Your guesses are also evaluated and one of the following state appear in each row:
You selected that the word belongs to the language and you were right.
You selected that the word belongs to the language and you were wrong.
You selected that the word does not belong to the language and you were right.
You selected that the word does not belong to the language and you were wrong.
You did not select anything, therefore you were wrong about the result.
While working with grammars, you can use two special symbols for various tasks, the Pipe and Epsilon

With the use of the Pipe you can divide the derivations which belong to the same rule, that way you can enter the grammar faster.
 In the following example the 2 grammars are equivalent:
 	 S -> aS | ε 
 
 	 S -> aS 
 	 S -> ε

The Epsilon symbol means the empty word. Epsilon is frequently used as the closing symbol of a grammar, and some languages also accept the empty word as a valid input. In the grammar definition activity you can enter the empty word by tapping the Epsilon button. During the grammar simulation activity, if you wish to test the empty word, leave the input field empty and Epsilon symbol gets added automatically.
You can save the grammar you are working on for future purposes or load existing grammars from external sources.

You can load existing grammars via the menu in the grammar definition activity by selecting the Load grammar button. The application supports 2 file formats, .cmsg which is the native CMSimulator file format and .jff which is the format used by a desktop application for grammar simulation called JFLAP. Therefore you can load grammars created in JFLAP and work with them in CMSimulator.

You can save the currently entered grammar via the menu in the grammar definition activity by selecting the Save grammar button. You have to enter a filename and chose between the 2 available formats .cmsg and .jff. If you chose .jff you can open the file in JFLAP. The file is saved to the CMSolutions folder in your device.
This app will help you with formal grammars and languages
When you click this button you can create new automata
This button allows you to create new grammar
Over here you can find tasks you have been assigned
Now we will create a new state
This will help you learn basic finite automata construction
Username must have 5 or more characters
Password must have 6 or more characters

Number of letters a or b has to be of 3k + 1
The word has to end with 01 or 10.
The letter a has to repeat N times.
The word consisting of a or b is followed by c, then the initial word is reversed.
The word is followed by its reversed form.
The letter a has to repeat N times followed by letter b repeated N times.
The letter a has to be repeated N times followed by letter b which has to repeat N times followed by letter c repeated N times.
There are two words w1 and w2 splited by $ sign. W2 is substring of w1.
Number multiplication by using only one algebraic operation exclusively.
